titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.37 Richmond, Va. Thursday February 12, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Movements of the enemy.
div3.p:
The latest information we have from the coast of North Carolina leads to the impression that the Federal forces recently threatening that section are moving in the direction of Charleston.
A correspondent of the Wilmington Journal, under date of the 7th, says that he had recently had a conversation with a gentleman who had just been released from imprisonment at Newbern, where he had opportunities of talking with some of the Yankee soldiers, and that he learned from them that the Yankee forces about Newbern were concentrating at Beaufort, N. C. He says that while he was in Newbern he heard the Yankees shouting "Hurrah for old South Carolinal" as if they were ordered there; and some of the troops told him they were going to Charleston.

The same correspondent writes, that a gentleman from the neighborhood of Swansboro' reports that seventeen of the enemy's boats passed that point on Saturday, and fifty-five on Sunday, about half of which were transports, or supposed to be such, from their size.

div3.head: Gen Bragg and his Generals.
div3.p: The Charleston Courier has the following paragraph about the present commander of the Army of the West:

q.p:
We learn from an unquestionable source that on the arrival of Gen Bragg at Tullahoma he addressed a circular letter to his Generals, in which he desired to know if there was any foundation for the rumor prevailing that there was dissatisfaction and a want of confidance in this existing in the army?
All the Generals with the exception of Withers and Cheatham replied in the affirmative, stating that such was the case, and that it would be to the interest of the service if Gen Bragg would ask to be relieved.
It is further stated that none but Generals Polk, Withers, and Cheatham concurred in the proposition to retreat from Murfreesboro', all the other Generals not only being opposed to it, but the majority of them were not even consulted on this point.

div3.p:
"The Campaign From Texas To Maryland, with the Battle of Fredericksburg," is the title of a very interesting work, written by Rev. Nicholas A. Davis, Chaplain of the 4th Texas Regiment.
It is a well written narrative of the experience of Hood's Texans since the opening of the war, and is amusing as well as entertaining.
It contains sketches of the lives of the officers of the brigade, and well executed lithographs of Major-Gen. Hood, and the late Lt. Col. Bradinte Warwick, of Richmond, who was killed at Gaines's Mill.

div3.head: Contribution.
div3.p:
--We have received a draft for $500 through Mr. B. R. Riordan, of the Charleston Mercury office, being the subscriptions made at that office for the relief of the Fredericksburg sufferers.
It will be handed to Mr. B. R. Howison Treasurer, and take the direction intended by the generous donors.

div3.head: Expulsion of women and children from St. Augustine.
div3.p:
--In accordance with an order from General Hunter, commending the "Department of the South," all the women and children in St., Augustine, Florida, having relatives in the Confederate service were expelled from that city on the 6th instant, and sent into our lines at Lake City.
The following is a list of those who were expelled:

Mrs. P. Andrew and three children, Mr. Joseph Baya and two children, Miss. C. Baya, Mrs. B. Bennet and child.
Mrs. Joseph Caps and three children, Mrs. Capella and two children, Mrs. W. Genovar and child, Mrs. J. V. Bernandez and three children, Mrs. E. Leonardy and five children, Mr. M. Leonardy and six children, G. M. Liambins D. J. Liembits, Joseph Liambits wife, and child, E. Masters and wife, Gab Masters and five children, Mrs. D. C. Mickier and three children, Miss P. Masters, Mrs. M. Neligan, Miss C. Neligan, Mrs. J. L. Thillips and child, Mrs. B. D. Pence and child, Miss F. Papy, Miss D. Papy, Miss C. Papy, Mrs. B. Pacetty and two children, Mrs. C. D. Segul and child, Mr. C. Pomar, wife, and four children, Miss Ellen Sanchez, Miss Eugernua Sanchez, Mrs. Williams, Miss V. Williams, Mr. Jos R. Pacetty, Mrs. F. Leonardy and two children, and Miss B. Masters.

div3.head: The rumors from Kentucky.
div3.p: --The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Rebel gives the following analysis of the recent rumors from Kentucky:

We understand from a reliable source that an Ohio brigade stationed at or near Louisville, Ky., having stolen a number of negroes recently had a very severe encounter with some Kentucky forces sent by Gen. Boyle, the Military Governor of that State, to recapture the negroes, and that severe loss in killed and wounded to each party was the result of the encounter.
This is the sum and substance of what has been magnified by rumor into a "severe and desperate" fight between the Kentuckians and the Yankees.
We hope there will be no necessity for a public meeting on this startling intelligence.

A gentleman writes us that the Yankee forces in the Blue grass country of Kentucky are as follows: "At Lexington, the 18th Kentucky, 250 strong, originally 1,000--these won't fight; also, 23d Michigan, 112th Illinois 8th Ohio cavalry, and a battery of artillery, and the 45th Ohio infantry.--At Frankfort, two regiments of infantry; at Winchester, none; at Mt. Sterling, Home Guards or Bushwhackers, about 400.
These are said to be all the Yankee troops in Eastern Kentucky--Gen. Granger, of Ohio, commanding the whole.

div3.head: A mystery Explained.
div3.p:
--The prevailing cries of "scarcity of supply" and "supply will soon be exhausted," were suddenly exploded in Columbus Ga., a few days since, by the occurrence of a fire.
The Sun gives the following account of the exposure of the speculative trick:

Sugar had become very scarce.
Consequently the price had gone up enormously.
Dealers constantly spoke of a probability, not very remote, that the supply would give out entirely, as "transportation" had become impossible.
Still the "supply" kept adequate to the demand.
When the hogsheads ran low fresh ones made their appearance.
The "supply" remained "steady and firm" There was always plenty on hand at the price asked for it. Railroad men said it had occasionally found its way out of the city of late but seldom into it. There was a strange mystery about it.--Steamboat men made similar statements.
Still the "supply" never gave out, although the price continued to go up. The fire occurred, the curtain was raised, the denoment appears, and the mastery is solved.
Broad street is literally full of huge hogsheads well filled with what had become so rare a luxury in our market.
Where did they come from?
Did they drop from the skies like the manna of old?
Did they spring from the earth like Minerva from the head of Jupiter?
Or, can it be possible that they emerged from quiet cellars and back rooms, in apprehension of the destroying element?

div3.head: Yankee Barbarity to negroes.
div3.p: --A correspondent writing from Fayette Court-House, Ala, under date of January 27, sends the following account of the barbarous treatment of two negro boys belonging to Mr. Nance, of Pickens county, Ala.:

A company of volunteers having left Pickens county for the field of action, Mr. Nance sent two negro boys along to aid the company.
Their imaginations became dazzled with the visions of Elysian fields in Yankeedom and they went to find them.
But Paradise was nowhere there, and they again signed for home.
The Yanks, however, detained them, and out off their ears close to their head.
These negroes finally made their escape, and are now at home, with Mr. Nance, in Fickens.
They are violent haters of Yankees; and their adventures and experience are a terror to negroes of that region, who learn a lesson from their brethren whose ears are left in Lincolndom"

div3.head: Handsome present to Gen. Bragg.
div3.p:
--The admirers of Gen. Bragg in Atlanta, Ga., have presented him with a saddle and bridle manufactured in that city.
The following is a description of what can be done by Southern manufacturers:

The bit is magnificent, glit with gold, ornamented on either side with a five pointed star, and is as elegantly finished as anything ever turned out of any Yankee shop.
The bridle has double reins and double head-staff, and the end of every strap is finished off with elegantly chased glit tips.
The head stall is ornamented with two glit rosettes with plain borders.
The face piece is very curiously, but beautifully shaped and wrought, the centre of which is ornamented with a finely glit stand of "grapes." The breast plate is large, and is a most elegantly finished piece of workmanship.
Its ornaments are the Confederate eagle, holding in its talons the Confederate flag with the stars and bars all complete, and the words "Come and take is" the laconte reply of Bragg to the demand of Rosecrans for the surrender of Murfreesboro', elegantly engraved thereon.

div3.head: Van-Dorn at Holly Springs.
div3.p: --The Tuscumbia North Alabamian, of the 50th ult., furnishes the following particulars of a recent raid of Van Dorn at Holly Springs:

A reliable gentleman who arrived in town yesterday from below reports that Gen. VanDorn made another attack on Daily spring a few days ago capturing 700 prisoner and cutting the 3d Michigan cavalry up very badly, only a few escaping.
The infamous scoundrel Capt who made himself infamous by his de no in this county, and who had been burning houses and cutting up extensively about Holly Springs, was hung by order of Van-Dorn only the minutes allowed him to make his arrangements for its long journey.

div3.head:
From Fredericksburg.
[from our own correspondent]
div3.p:
Abu, evarit--Hookert is the testimony of Rumor's thousand tongues about here.
Before reaching town yesterday I heard our signal corps was signifying that the enemy were off towards the Potomac, and up towards Dumfries.
Then there were numerous firer, mornings and evenings.
One man saw several regiments stack arms, burn their tents, (?) and go off in the carr, etc. Also, we hear that McClellan has taken command.
These are a few of the "thousand and one" reports afloat here.

You want to hear "from Fredericksburg." I give what is heard in Fredericksburg.
Perhaps it is because Gen. Hooker has forbidden the exchange of newspapers for several days past, another evidence that there is something to conceal; and a presumption that his "movement" is going on, and meant to be concealed.
The same thing occurred before Burnsides Monday excursion up the river.
No papers were allowed to come over.
If this weather holds — damp, and rain, and slight snow flakes in the air — Hooker's movement will be another slick in the mud concern, and the Army of the Potomac will be extinguished.

So far you have had full benefit of Northern papers received here, and shall continue to do so, whenever, by fair exchange, the Yankees are disposed to give and receive our respective publications.
To say truth however, I sympathise with those who would rather "exchange" blows than newspapers.
That would more accord with the deep detestation and cordial contempt their insulting and critical presence on our soil excites.
We accept their papers in exchange not as favors, but as evidences to prove their falsehood, villainous purposes, and internal wrangling and disgusting mal-administration of what they have made a miserable caricature of Government.

By way of offset and reply to their everlasting snorting of steam engines smoke and racket, day and night, our gallant Mississippians had a grand dress parade yesterday evening.
The splendid band of the 16th Mississippi discoursed inspiring music for Col, Humphrey heroes of the 21st, whose drill appearance and material fit them for the name and reputation they have "so nobly won." The Yankees seemed to be surprised at the sounds, and probably hurried their "movement."

To catch the mail I must close.
Pity its "facilities" are not extended to Fredericksburg.
The Richmond and Fredericksburg railroad does its work well.
The President, Superintendent, and all its officers have excelled themselves.
Let the Post Office Department assist to deliver a daily mail in Fredericksburg.

div3.head:
The Yankee dash into Warrenton.
[Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
div3.p:
Five hundred Yankee cavalry dashed into Warrenton.
Fauquier county, last Tuesday night about 12 o'clock, and staying two hours gave the citizens of that unfortunate little village another illustration of the character of our Northern brothers.--The Federal party was commanded by the English gentleman, (1) Sir Percy Windham Colonel, who, during his night raid, allowed his hirelings to rob and plunder as much as they possibly could in the short time they thought it advisable to remain in town.
They broke open stores and jewelry shops, and stole and robbed everything they could lay their hands on such as jewelry, watches, tobacco, and horses mostly belonging to citizens.--Gathering up their body, 500 men (soldiers) found themselves stealthily retiring from Warrenton under cover of darkness, with nothing to compensate them for their trouble but the happy reflection that they, with their usual gallentry, had added new lustre to the fame of the United States by capturing a town wrapped in the folds of sleep; robbing unoffending citizens, among them a helpless widow; taking about ten horses, but not a prisoner; some watches, and a little tobacco.
Their mission accomplished, they hastened to return to camp before day.

All was well so far, but camp had not been reached.
A squad of the Black Horse, (Lieut. S.) whose movements or where abouts are not known either to friend or foe; soon found out what was going on. They assembled in less than an hours time, took their position on the road, and as the enemy passed by on their return, took two of the advance guard about one hundred yards in advances; another coming up to see why the advance guard halted, was taken also.
Some others falling behind, near Buckland, shared the same fate.
That night the Black Horse pursued them as far as Bull Run, capturing in all eight prisoners, seven horses, some pistols, carbines, hats, canteens, etc. without the loss of a single man. It is hoped Warrenton will be relieved from further molestation from the enemy, for certainly two reasons operate to make their visits there both unprofitable and unsafe. --So much has the county suffered from marauding parties that now there is very little to invite even Yankee robbers headed by the accomplished and skillful English night robber Wincham; and so quick and mysterious are the movements of the Black Horse that when a raid is made up in the county, night or day, the enemy generally returns to camp with his numbers considerably diminished Privates captured agree in stating that the officers would not allow them to rob the stores, but appropriated the valuables themselves.
The Black Horse has recently more than curtained its high reputation for gallantry.
Composed of some of Virginia's noblest sons, it would be strange, indeed, if in the moment of our country's peril the members should fall to make a reputable exhibition of gallantry.

div3.head:
Cavalry raid.
[Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
div3.p:
On the late cavalry raid in the direction of Alexandria, we took about two hundred prisoners--of which number Capt Brawner's Partisans captured fifteen. He captured a squad of their pickets one night in the following manner: The Captain rode out into the country, several miles from the road upon which our troops were marching, to see a friend residing there, taking one man with him.--On approaching the house, he observed men and horses in and about the yard.
It being too dark to distinguish uniforms he rode up among them.
Seeing that they were cavalrymen he inquired, "What cavalry is this?" "Union cavalry, sir," was the reply. "What regiment?" "First Maryland" responded several. "All right, then," replied the Captain, turning his horse and riding slowly off at the same time, leaving the Yankees in doubt as to which army be belonged.

He soon got a detachment of his men, returned, and captured the whole party, with their horses, equipments, &c., without haling a man injured.--His friend was greatly rejoiced at being relieved so unexpectedly from his oppression and humiliation, these unprincipled wretches having been quartered upon him for several weeks, with the privilege of taking, without compensation, whatever they desired.
To remonstrate with them was only to invite taunts and insults.

A few troops acquainted with the country could give great protection to the citizens and their property in those exposed sections, by checking these bands of robbers, who are constantly going wherever they can venture.

div3.head: The resolutions for Stopping the war introduced in the Indiana Legislature.
div3.p:
Two sets of resolutions have been introduced in the Indiana Legislature looking to the stoppage of this war. The first were presented by Mr. Well, of Washington county, on the 23th ultimo.
The preamble sets forth that the people have been forced into this war by "the wicked and fanatical factions North and South," which is filling the land "with widows, orphans, and mourning households;" that it is filling the Northern section of the Union with a vagabond and servile race to compete with or prey upon the industry of the white man; imposing unequal burdens and commercial restrictions upon the different portions of the North thereby increasing the danger and the evil of further disintegration; sapping the foundation of religion, morality, and public virtue; corrupting our rulers by an increase of political patronage; destroying personal liberty under the tyrant a plan of necessity; and obliterating from the hearts of the people the spirit of nationality and brotherhood, which is the only sure bond of Union.
The preamble continues:

Whereas, Experience has taught the costly and bloody lesson that war signs is the only remedy for the evil of disunion; but waged in the spirit of sectional hatred for an unconstitutional purpose, or in a manner not sanctioned by the laws of civilised warfare, it is the strongest ally of disunion, and if persisted in will result not only in the bankruptcy of the nation and the impoverishment of the people, but also in a final separation of the different sections and the destruction of our admirable form of free government; and.

Whereas. The people of Indiana are desirous that no effort which inspires a reasonable hope of success in restoring the Union as it was under the Constitution shall be omitted, and being solemnly impressed with the conviction that arms alone under the recent and present policy of the Cabinet at Washington will never accomplish that desirable object, and invoking the prayers of all goodmen and the smiles of a God of Peace in the furtherance of our patriotic purpose: Therefore.

Be it resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Indiana.
That while we continue to obey every which true patriot demand for the purpose of restoring the Union and preserving constitutional liberty, yet we are opposed in a war for the liberation of the slaves; and while that policy is maintained by the Administration the highest distastes of patriotism hope as to withhold from it our support believing that a war for that purpose is unconstitutional, and, if persisted in, will lead to the inevitable and lasting destruction of the Union.

2. That no Union can be maintained in this country until fanaticism on the negro question, North and South, is eradicated and the doctrine of Popular State Sovereignty is acknowledged as a fundamental axiom of the Government.
The people of the North must yield up the hereby of Abolitionism, or else yield up the blessings of the Union--Abolitionism and the Union are incompatible — he one or the other must triumph.
A war for Abolitionism is a war against the Abolitionism.
Abolitionism is moral treason, and but for the forms of law with which it is clothed by the Administration, is actual legal treason.
No patriot can be an Abolitionist.

3. That the interest of the white race, as well as the black, demands that the condition and locality of the latter should not be interfered with; and a war, or legislation, or Presidentist proclamations to accomplish the purpose of the negro's freedom and consequent migration to the North, are acts of flagrant violation of the Constitution, and in wicked disregard of the people's voice and the best interests of the country and all such acts ought to be constitutionally resisted by an outraged people.

4. That President Lincoln's scheme of "compensated emancipation." which proposse to tax the people of Indians to liberate the slaves of the South, is unconstitutional and a monstrous iniquity, which a tax ridden and over-burdened people will not submit to. The freemen of Indiana will not consent to impoverish themselves and their families to carry out that insane and wicked policy, but will resist it by every constitutional means in their power.

5. That the system of arbitrary arrests and wanton disregard of the great Writ of Liberty, commonly called the habeas corpus, by the Cabinet of Washington, are acts of tyranny and usurpation, justly alarming to a free people, against which the of Indiana protests with indignation and in the name of constitutional liberty she demands that the accursed system shall cease within her borders; and we declare the unalterable determination of the people to maintain the liberty of speech, the liberty of the press the right to the writ of habeas corpus and speedy trial by jury at every hazard of blood and treasure.

6. That the State of Indiana, on account of her devotion to the Union, and her geographical position and commercial interests, never will consent to any settlement upon a basis of disunion, or a policy which shall separate her from the States bordering upon the Mississippi river.
Her highest interest demands the perpetuation of the Union, and especially that the great Valley of the Mississippi, from its source to its mouth, shall remain under one Government and one flag.

7. That the war in which we are engaged ought to cease as soon as it can be brought to an honorable and satisfactory termination; and upon that subject the people who are hearing its burdens have a right to speak.
Therefore, our Senators in Congress are instructed, and our Representatives requested, to use all the power and influence of their positions by bill, resolution or otherwise to accomplish the following objects, viz: 1.
To procure an armistice of at least six months between the Federal and Confederate armies, for the purpose of testing the possibility of a permanent peace on the basis of the Union.
2. To pass a law calling a Convention of all the States, composed of delegates freely chosen by the people to take into consideration the state of the country, and to devise some plan of settlement, to be submitted to a vote of the people, North and South, by which the Union shall be preserved and the country restored to a lasting peace.
3. That the Governor be directed to transmit a certained copy of the foregoing preamble and resolutions to each of our Senators and Representatives in Congress, to be laid before their respective bodies, and to the Governor of each of the States to be by them laid before their respective Legislatures.
On the 30th ult., Mr. Brown, of Wells county, submitted the following joint resolutions:

q.p: Whereas, We believe that the following language: "Suppose you go to war, you cannot fight always, when, after much loss on both sides and no gain on either, you cease fighting, the old identical: questions as to the terms of intercourse are again upon you," embodies great truths and wisdom: Therefore.

div3.p: Resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Indiana, That it is the imperative duty of the Chief Executive of the nation to proclaim, and we, therefore, for and in the name of the people of the State of Indiana, demand the establishment, as soon as practicable, of an armistice, to the end that a Convention of all the States may be held for the adjustment of our national difficulties.

Resolved, That we hereby instruct our Senators and request our Representatives in Congress, to labor to provide, and for and in the name of the people of the State of Indiana, we demand, that the present Congress shall provide for a Convention of all the States to be holden at some suitable point, at the earliest practicable period, with a view to the restoration of the Union, with all the dignity, equality, and right of the several States unimpaired.

Resolved, That in the event of the present Congress felling to provide for such Convention we hereby, in the name of the people of the State of Indiana, invite each and every State in the Federal Union, including the so-called Confederate States, to meet delegates from the State of Indiana in Convention at Nashville, Tennessee, on the first Monday, it being the first day of June 1864, each of said States to send as many delegates to said Convention as shall equal the number of Senators and Representatives to which each State is entitled in the Congress of the United States, according to the census of 1860.

Resolved, That for the purpose of carrying out, on the part of the State of Indiana, the object set forth in the two last foregoing resolutions, there shall be elected, on the first Monday in April, 1863, in the usual manner, and at the usual places of holding elections, thirteen delegates from the State at large to represent Indiana in said Convention at Nashville, Tennessee, unless the present Congress shall provide for a Convention as in the second of these resolutions designed, in which case said delegates shall represent Indiana in such Convention; and the election of said delegates shall be certified to the Governor of the State, and the commissions shall issue to them in the manner as nearly as the same may be practicable, provided by sections 44 and 45 of the act regulating general elections.
And further, in the event of the present Congress failing to provide for a Convention, at designed in the second of these resolutions, said delegates shall be entitled to a peridium of $5 during their attendance upon said Convention at Nashville, and a milleage at the rate of five cents per mile for every mile necessarily traveled in going to and returning from said Convention, which perdiem and mileage shall be drawn from the state Treasury upon the warrant of the Auditor of the State, issued to the Treasurer of the State, upon a certificate of service from the presiding officer of said Convention.

Resolved, That the Governor of this State transmit, or cause to be transmitted, a copy of these resolutions to the President of the United States, the Congress of the United States, and the Governors and Legislatures of each and all the States in the Federal Union, including the so-called Confederate States.

The Chicago (Ill.) Times, commenting on these resolutions, says its country wants an honorable peace.
It is sick — sick unto death, of this unprofitable war. It says:

q.p:
The terms of settlement may very property be left with the Convention.
Its actions should not be embarrassed by premature discussion.
A settlement agreed upon by the entire body of the seceded States, by the border and conservative Democratic States, would compel respect and obedience.
New England would much rather sacrifice her fanaticism than her connection with the Union.
If she will not consent to terms of peace acceptable to the balance of the Union, she can step aside.

div3.p:
If there is a hope remaining for the restoration of the Government, it is in a peace that will secure to every section of our Confederacy the sacred guarantees of the Constitution.
The impossibility of subjugating the South has already been demonstrated.
The contest, as at present waged will only exhaust each party, without leading to decisive results.
It is nonsense to talk of our exterminating five and a half millions of people such as we have been fighting for the past two years.

The Indianapolis (Ind.) Journal, on the same subject, speaks very differently.
It says:

q.p:
It places before the Union people of Indiana the issue, Union or no Union.
If Indiana can, while the Government of which it is a part is fighting for its existence, turn away and make peace for itself, Indiana is no longer in the Union.
This measure, if passed, will take our State out of the Union as surely as an ordinance of Secession.
It is an ordinance of Secession.
It was meant to be. Now.
Indianians, you who have sons, and brothers and fathers fighting for the Union, who have given your best and dearest to preserve it, you are called to a new effort that all you have hitherto done may not be a waste of blood.
Traitors at home have introduced into your Legislature a Secession ordinance, and if they pass it you have accomplished nothing but your own ruin by all you have done.
They have taken advantage of the absence of 60,000 loyal men to push the State to the verge of Secession, and now they are openly preparing to give it the last the fatal threat.
They shall not accomplish it without a fight such as their coward hearts never dreamed of; but we must avoid bloodshed at home, if possible.
It is yours to prevent it.

div3.head: From Havana.
div3.p:
--The pilot beat Relief, from Havana, has arrived at Mobile.
There was no news of interest at Havana when the Relief left, on the 19th ult. The people were so convinced that we shall have an early peace, that there was to demand for action at the prices asked for it. The cotton which was recently received had been shipped to Europe.

div3.head: Important to Louisiana soldiers.
div3.p: --Among the acts passed at a recent extra session of the Louisiana Legislature was the following: "An act to appropriate fifty dollars and eighty acres of land to every soldiers from this State in the State or Confederate service."
Hon. I. Welsh, M. C., from Mississippi, was thrown from a vehicle near Macon, Miss., a few weeks since, fracturing his shoulder

div4.p: Senate.--The Senate was called to order as 12 o'clock M., by Mr. Hunter, of Va., and opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Secley, of the Baptist Church.

Mr. Maxwell, of Florida, submitted a resolution, directing the Committee on the Judiciary to inquire into the expediency of so amending the laws relating to the mileage of District Attornies of the C. States, as to allow mileage for all necessary travel in going to and returning from the Courts on the route most usually traveled, and to report by bill or otherwise.
A petition of John Rample, presented by Mr. Brown, of Miss., was referred to the Committee on Claims.
Mr. Davis of N. C., from the Committee on CL to whom was referred the petition of G. W. "Vang reported it back, with the request that the committee be discharged from its further consideration.

He also reported back certain joint resolutions, in the shape of a bill, for the relief of John F. Device, with a recommendation that it pass.
Devince as quartermaster at Fort Macon when that post was about to fell into the hands of the Abolition forces, had destroyed $1,000 worth of C. S. Treasury notes in his possession.
The bill was intended to restore him that amount.
It was passed.

Mr. P of Miss., from the committee to whom was referred the bill providing for the impressment and appropriation of cotton by the Government, reported it back, with two sections added by way of amendment, which the committee recommend do pass.
Laid on the table, printed and made the order of the day for Monday next.

The next business to order being the motion of Mr. Clay, of Ale, to strike out sections 45 and 46 of the bill of the Provisional Congress organizing the Supreme Court of the Confederate States, it was informally passed over, and the Senate went into secret session, on motion of Mr. Clark, of Mo., to consider the report of the committee forming the Standing Committees.
On the opening of the doors, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by the Speaker.

The Chair announced the following Special Committee, authorized by the House on the subject of abuses in railroad transportation, viz: Messrs. Atkins of Tenn; Bridges, of N. C.; Mannerlyn, of Ga; Simpson, of S. C., and Collier, of Va.

Memorials.--Mr. Gartrell.
of Ga., submitted a memorial from Gen. Duff Green, respectfully representing that be had devoted much time and labor to the study of the subjects of finance and currency, and had prepared an argument urging the necessity, and, as he believes, demonstrating the power and duty of Congress to make Treasury notes a legal tender; which, with an appendix containing a mass of valuable statistics bearing on these subjects, he respectfully submitted for the consideration of the House.
The memorial was laid upon the table, when Mr. Gartrell submitted the argument referred to, and moved that it be printed for the use of the House.
Messrs Jones, of Tenn., and Lyons, of Va. opposed the reception of the argument and Mr. Foote, of Tenn, addressed the House briefly in favor of its reception.

Mr. Jones of Tenn., moved that the House decline to receive the document; and the question being called on this motion, the ayes and noes were demanded on the rejection of the argument, and resulted — ayes 33 noes 45.
So the House refused to reject the communication.
Mr. Gartrell then moved that the communication be referred to the Committee of Ways and Means; which was agreed to.
Mr. Gartrell then modified his motion to print by moving to refer that question to the Committee on Printing.

Mr. Jones, of Tenn., moved to lay the motion to refer to Committee on Printing on the table, and upon this motion the ayes and noes were ordered, and resulted ayes 61.
noes 17.
On motion of Mr. Lyons, of Va., the House then went into secret session.

Senate.--The Senate met at 12 M, the President in the chair.
Opened with prayer by the Rev. Mr. Pettigrew.

A communication from the Executive, transmitted, in response to a resolution of the Senate, copies of all contracts entered into by the State Government with the proprietors of iron works for the hire of negro convicts.
Referred and ordered to be printed.

Bills Offered.--A bill to increase the allowance for the board and lodging of jurors in criminal cases.
A bill declaring what contracts shall be payable in currency.
A bill authorizing a tollbridge over Dan river, at Wilison's Ferry.

Resolutions.--By Mr. Newman: A preamble and joint resolution in relation to on increase of pay to the non commissioned offices and soldiers of the Confederate service, and instructing the Virginia Representatives in Congress to use their influence in bringing about the desired increase.
By Mr. Dickinson: Looking to the sale of the State stock in public improvements at part or below par, and their investment in the 8 per cent, stock of the Confederate States as a sinking fund to pay the bonds of the State, as they may fall due from time to time.
The committee to whom was referred the bill increasing the salaries of the State Department clerks, reported back the same with amendments.
Pending the discussion, on motion of Mr. Pennybacker, at 3 o'clock the Senate adjourned.
[Note--On motion of Mr. Thompton Messrs. Coghill and Lynch were added to the Committee on the Salt Bill]

div4.head: House of delegates.
div4.p:
--The House met at the usual hour.
Prayer by Rev. Dr. Jeter.

Mr. Anderson, from the Committee on Military Affairs submitted a report asking to be discharged from the consideration of a resolution exempting from military service one deputy clerk for each county, and one deputy sheriff for every twelve thousand inhabitants.
Request granted.

Resolutions of Inquiry--The following resolutions of inquiry were introduced: By Mr. Fleming: What legislation is necessary, if any, to enable the County Courts to order elections where in consequence of the presence of the public enemy, elections cannot take place according to existing laws.
By Mr. Lockridge: Into the expediency of reporting a bill providing for the punishment of persons who go about the country purchasing produce by falsely representing themselves as agents of the Government and aid societies.
By Mr. Marye: Into the expediency of providing for the election of county officers where no such elections have been held because of the presence of the public enemy.
By Mr. Mayo: Into the expediency of amending the Code so as to increase the amount paid for each cask, hogshead, or other parcel of tobacco, weighing not less than five hundred pounds, for the use of the State.

Mr. Garrison submitted a resolution reviving the Select Committee appointed to inquire into the loyalty of Judges of the state and into the expediency of impeaching Judge H. P. Pitts, of the Accomac district.
Mr. Garrison stated that Judge P. was now holding a commission under the Commonwealth and drawing his pay from her Treasury, when it was well known and could be proven beyond a doubt that he was administering the law under that traitorous and usurped Government of Pierpoint, and that he even required the small bar which still remained in his district to take the oath of allegiance to the Lincoln Government before they were permitted to practice in his Courts.
It was for these reasons that he asked his impeachment.
The resolution was agreed to.

On motion of Mr. Anderson of Botetourt, the rules were suspected, and the bill amending an act passed 14th of May, 1862 authorizing 10,000 men to be raises for the defence of the Commonwealth, was taken up, read a second time, and recommitted to the Committee on Military Affairs.

Mr. Ambers presented a petition from Col. W. B. Ball, asking the relief of his successor as Captain of the Chesterfield cavalry from obligation to the State for forty pairs of shoes drawn from the penitentiary in the spring of 1861, upon the order of the petitioner, all papers relating to their disposition, &c., having been lost.
Referred to Committee on Finance.
The bill establishing general agents and storekeepers for counties and corporations was taken up and passed — ayes 4 noes 18.

On motion of Mr. Hunter, the resolution of the committee relative to legalizing Confederate currency was taken up. Some discussion arose on the subject, when Mr. Hunter further moved its indefinite postponement which was not agreed to.
An ineffectual effort was made to make it the order of the day for Friday next; so the bill consequently lies upon the table.
Mr. Mo and submitted the following resolution, which he gave notice he should at the proper time offer as a substitute for the report of the committee:

Resolved That in the opinion of the General Assembly of Virginia, the Congress of the Confederate States, if in their opinion they have the constitutional power, should make the notes issued by the Confederate Government a legal tender in payment of debts; and our Senators and Representatives are requested to bring this subject as once to the attention of Congress, and urge its speedy action thereon.

Mr. Hopkins, of Petersburg, called up the bill chartering the "Submarine Battery Joint Stock Company," for the blowing up of the enemy's frigates, sloops-of-war, gunboats, etc. according to the plan of David Smith.
Ordered to its engrossment.
On motion, the House adjourned.

div3.head: Destructive fire
div3.p:
--The extensive distilitery of Messrs. Mason, Harman & Co., on the extrem east and of Main street, at Rocketts on the bluff overlooking James river at that point, was fired by an incendiary about 1 o'clock on Tuesday night, and, together with its whole contents, totally destroyed.
This distillery was erected by Messrs Steared & Brummel, and was used for several years by them.
Some months since it was sold by Franklin Stearns to Messrs C. R. Mason, G. D. Earman, and John Mayo, who were manufacturing whiskey for the Government at the time of its destruction.
About $30, 000 worth of grain and malt were destroyed with the building, which was very large and complete in all its appointments.
The destruction of property by fire on this occasion must have largely exceeded $100, 000.

The fire on the south side of the Deck, which occurred on Monday, (heretofore noticed.) burned up the dwelling-house of Robert W. Allen and its contents — the whole valued at $3,000 on which there was no insurance.
Fires have been of frequent concurrence for several weeks past.

div3.head: Libby prison.
div3.p:
--Nine Yankees were brought to this prison on yesterday from North Carolina--Their names are B. H. Goldsmith, John Whisley, A. Stom, and Daniel Sterr, belonging to the butler's Department of the Yankee army; Samuel Merdit and James Keyes, seamen aboard the ship Underwriter, and W. W. Williams and John Jackson, privates of co. B. 1st N. Y. cavalry, and W. C. Bouge, seaman aboard the steamer Commodore Perry.
The three last deserted from the Yankees.
Those of the above who were captured were taken near Chowan river, North Carolina, January 28th. Yesterday there were in this prison 213 Yankee prisoners war, 118 citizen gross — total with those who arrived yesterday 425 men.

div3.head: A Desperado.
div3.p:
--John Middlin, a member of the 28th North Carolina regiment was brought to Castle Thunder yesterday, heavily ironed, and lodged there for trial before the Court-Martial.
It appears that Middlin deserted from his regiment, and that on one of his brother soldiers and the Lieutenant of his company attempting to arrest him he badly wounded the man and killed the officer.

div3.head: Recruits for the Army.
div3.p:
--Forty men were sent to the Army of the Potomac yesterday, under guard, in charge of Detectives Perdue and New, to be returned to the several regiments from which they had taken the liberty of absenting themselves at various periods without permission.
Descriptives lists are taken of all soldiers thus returned, and should they are found delinquent a second time it goes hard with them.

div3.head: Left Richmond.
div3.p:
--George Moore, Her Britannie Majesty's Consul at the port of Richmond was among the passengers who left by the last flag of truces for the North on Monday last.
He went to Petersburg by private conveyance, and left on the flag of truce boat from City Point.
His business is doubtless with the British Minister at Washington.
Its peculiar nature did not transpire prior to his leaving.

div3.head: Deaths of soldiers.
div3.p:
--Two soldiers, named James Cline, of company E, 37th North Carolina, and Jno, R. Page, company C, 54th Virginia died in the hospital of the military prison of the Eastern District yesterday.
They were sent there to be returned to their regiments.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p: --Present: Recorder Caskie, and Aldermen Sanxay, Beveridge, Regnault, and Lipscombs.

Reuben, slave of James H. Taylor, charged with stealing $115 in Confederate Treasury notes from Samuel D. Pullen, on the 11th day of January, was had to the bar, and John S. Caskie being assigned his counsel, he was tried and declared not guilty.

Adam Shafer, a white man, was examined for having, on the 3d inst, stolen $1,000 in C. S. Treasury notes, the property of Thomas B. Hubbard.--The witness and defendant boarded together, at Mrs. Graves's, corner of Mayo and Franklin streets.
The robbery was accomplished in a room occupied jointly by them.
Defendant was sent on.

Henry, slave of William G. Taylor, was tried for having, on the 15th of January, stolen from Thos. E. Ballard a leather trunk, valued at $40, and its contents consisting of a variety of wearing apparel. Benjamin H. Nash, of Chesterfield, was assigned consul for defendant, who was tried found guilty, and ordered to be punished with thirty nine stripes.

The case of Thomas D. Hudgins, charged with grand larceny, was called, but the defendant did not respond, though the Sergeant demanded his presence (as the record hath it) "solemnly." It appears that on the 15th of January, Hudgins stole a blanket worth $40, one pair of saddle pockets, worth 430, and sundry other articles of value, the property of Lewis D. Spencer, for which the Mayor sent him on to the hustings Court.
On the 22d of January, Mr. John G. Scotts libasted by going his ball in the sum of $330. The Court issued coples for the arrest of the defendant.

To-morrow (Thursday) the misdemeanor docket, which is very heavy this term, will be called.
The case of Rodgers alias Manning, and Lynne alias Mason, bogus officers, arrested for being substitute agents and swindlers, will be called at 11 o'clock, on the assembling of the Court.
The witnesses in this case should be prompt in their attendance.
Mayor's Court, Wednesday Feb. 11.--The cares before His Honor today were not of the first order of importance.
John, slave of John W. McKiel, was ordered a lashing for having in his possession four bottles of whiskey, for whose possession he could not satisfactorily account.

Joseph L. Price was arraigned for wandering about the streets drunk, and having no place to stay.
The Mayor provided for his want in the latter respect.
A few negroes were ordered to be whipped for being without passes, and the Court adjourned.

div3.head: Northern news Via Mississippi.
div3.p: --A dispatch dated Jackson, Miss., 11th, says the Crisis has the following dispatch from Grenada:

q.p:
Chicago dates of the 4th and New York dates of the 3d, are received.
Dry goods have advanced beyond the reach of greenbacks.
Gold 162½.

div3.p: Twelve Confederate prisoners were frozen to death at Camp Douglas.
The Kentucky Legislature has ordered out 23,000 troops, under the Military Board, to resist the enforcement of Lincoln's proclamation in that State.
[Much later dates than the above have been received and published, in which the reported action of the Kentucky Legislature is not mentioned.--The rumor is doubtless incorrect.]

div3.head: From Louisiana.
div3.p:
--Information has just been received here that a portion of Sibley's command encountered the enemy at Indian Village today, routing him, after a severe fight.
The enemy admits a loss of one thousand killed, wounded, and missing.

We have positive information from Baton Rouge that the Irish brigade and a negro regiment have been sent below.
The total force of the enemy is 19,000.
Deserters are continually arriving here.
[Indian Village in situated on the Bayon Techer in St. Mary's Parish, La, about sixty miles southwest of Port Hudson by an airline]

div3.head: Desirable family residence and two stores rooms, and other Real estate, at auction.
div3.p: --I will sell on Thursday, the 19th of this month, (February.) commencing at 11 o'clock, that most desirable property on Main street, in the town of Charlottesville, at present occupied in part by myself as a family residence and store-room — the other store-room being rented.

The family residence has 10 rooms and 3 closets, and is one of the meat comfortable and conveniently arranged in the town for a large family — would admit of being occupied by two families, and has gas in every room.
The store rooms are large and well adapted to a large mercantile business, being favorably located and having lumber-rooms attached.
There are also attached to the promises comfortable out-houses — as kitchen, rooms for servants, a smoke house and stable, and a pump of good water.
On the same day, I will sell a desirable Office, on Court street adjoining the offices of Alex'r Rives and E. R. Watson, R. qs.

Also, on the same day, two Building Lots, fronting the residences of E. R. Watson, Esq. Judge Wm. J. Robertson, and in part that of Mrs. Julia A Holiday.
These lots being located in the most desirable part of the town, offer especial inducements to those wishing to build.
Altogether, a very attractive opportunity is presented for profitable and safe investment; and those wishing to purchase are invited to examine the property.
Terms--Cash; or at 1, 2 and 3 years, at the option of the purchaser.
div3.closer:
John C. Patterson.
Charlottesville. Feb. 5. 1863. fe 9--5t*

div3.head: Seventy five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Is offered for the apprehension and delivery of my slave William Henry, who disappeared from the fortifications around Richmond about the 10th of December.
Said slave is about 19 years of age, 5 feet high, thick set, thick of speech, gruff in manner of speaking, and generally clears his throat before beginning; has a peculiarly formed head, protuberance on the back of it, and eyes somewhat popped.
The above reward is offered for the apprehension and delivery of said slave to me in Danville, or lodged in the jail in Richmond so that I get him in possession.

div3.head: Runaway--$5 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran off from the subscriber from Union Hill, on the 2d inst., a black Girl of the name of Zuliam.
She lived last year with Mrs. Petty, on Main street, between 20th and 21st streets.
She is a thick set, stout Girl, round face, aged about 20 years. I will give the above reward on her delivery to me, or to where I can get her.

div3.head: Office City Gas Works, January 28th 1863.
div3.p:
Four hundred Dollars reward.--Ranaway, from the City Gas Works, four negro men. Ro Hughes is about 6 feet high, dark skin, and about 25 years old; Richid Nelson, 5 feet 6 or 9 inches high, mulatto, and about 23 years olds, Frank, 5 feet 8 inches high, dark skin, and about 25 years old. Frank was formerly on the York River railroad.
Elijah Camphell, 5 feet 10 inches high, dark skin, and about 23 years old. The above reward will be paid for the delivery of the four or $100 for the delivery of either one at the City Gas Works, Rocketts.

div3.head: Beautiful Improved farm, near Charlottesville and Twelve or fifteen negroes, for sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs. Crawford and als," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the premires, on Tuesday the 3d day of March, 1863.
(or the next fair day.) a beautiful estate, known as Meadow Creek, containing about 600 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia, has an abundance of timber; in smooth and gently undulating, inacceptible of a high degree of improvement, has a large creek entirely through the place, affording a quantity-of fine meadow land, well set in old grass, yielding a large quantity of bay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling house, and all the necessary out-houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, in offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Mitch Cows, &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the options of the purchaser.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 37, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company, by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money as be sent should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia, and scaled with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully there directions, and follow them.

div3.head: The African soldiers.
div3.p:
Horace Grosley is enthusiastic in his praises of the qualities of "American citizens of African descent" as soldiers, and declares, that they have more dash, ardor, &c., than the Northern warriors.
How the white men of the Northern army will relish this compliment is another question.
The United States has ransacked the world for soldiers, and the most efficient part of its army in Virginia is made up of Irishmen and Germans, who have always enjoyed the reputation of being among the best fighting men of Europe.
It may be doubted whether Europe ever saw a finer body of soldiers than that Irish brigade of Meagher, which was annihilated at the battle of Fredericksburg.
They were not only splendidly disciplined, but were men of extraordinary physical power — giants in stature and muscle.
When Horace imagines that Africans will prove more formidable soldiers than such men, he shows how far negrophoble can beset the human understanding.

But somebody must be got to fight — anybody but Horace and his Black Republicans.
The raising of negro levies is, of course, an admission that no more white men can be got. The inhua salty of employing such instruments to ravage the South might deserve some comment, if the impotency of the scheme were not equal to its malice.
Whenever these crows alight upon Southern cornfields, the smell of gunpowder was soon teach them the value of discretion.
But in this, as in other features of the war, the Yankees are at least true to their own principles.
They were the first inventors and exclusive proprietors of Know Nothingism, and having failed in consequence of Southern opposition to get rid of their foreigners, they have persuaded them to emigrate in armies, and be killed off like cattle.
They were the inventors and chief patrons of Abolitionism; but having failed in that also, they are now preparing to abolish all the negroes they can lay hold of by sending them after the foreigners.

div3.head: Raise wheat and corn.
div3.p:
It is to be hoped that every planter and farmer of the South who has a spark of patriotism will abstain from the cultivation of cotton and tobacco, and give every acre of the soil to the production of corn, wheat, peas, potatoes, and every description of food for man and beast.
Even in a mercenary point of view — and it is humiliating that this has become in these times too common a principle of action — these productions will pay better than any others.
The man who raises cotton and tobacco now is not only aiming a blow at the independence of his country, but at what, perhaps, he values more, his own interests.
The only enemy we have to fear is the sacrifies of the common good to individual greed.
One more year of self denial, and, in all probability, the South can return to the cultivation of its peculiar staples with safety and profit.

div3.head: Cotton bales.
div3.p:
The employment of cotton bales to resist shot by both Confederate and Federal vessels, seems to have proved a successful experiment.
Possibly they may yet rival the iron clads — another triumph of King Cotton, which could scarcely have been anticipated.
If useful for vessels, they must be equally so in land defences.
The cotton breast-works employed by Gen. Jackson at the battle of New Orleans may again be adepted with equal success.
At all events, the material is cheap and plenty, and the experiment would not be a costly one.

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper with to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest will be paid.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --The Chaplains on duty in the near this city are respectfully requested to meet in the Mission Room of the Baptist Church, this (Thursday) evening, at 4 o'clock.

div3.head: To the Voters of Virginia.
div3.p: --Fellow-citizens: Having been requested by many of you to become a candidate for the office of Governor at the regular election in May next, I respectfully announce that I cheerfully yield to such request, and, in the even of my election will diligently and to the best of my ability perform the duties of the position.

I am sensible of the responsibilities which I announce my willingness to assume.
I am painfully aware of the giant sturgle which is in progress and that it may be my duty to assume such responsibilities without counting the cost to myself in such even I shall unhesitatingly do so, only asking the liberal construction of my fellow-citizens for my vindication and defence.

I regret that it will not be in my power to appear among you and address you upon public affairs.
But having deemed it my duty to adhere to the army, to which, after a confinement of some months, I am about to return, I shall not have an hour to open for any other purpose.
I regret this the less however, as I flatter myself that I am sufficiently well known to you in person, or by reputation, to enable you to exercise the sovereign power of suffrage with all proper intelligence.

With no parties to divide us — with but one great impulse — that which seeks to protect our liberties and establish our independence — we surely can work together with one will to realize this vital consummation.
At any rate, if elected.
I shall seek to deserve your confidence by devoting to the duties of my position all the powers of mind and body which I possess.
Belloving, if true to ourselves, that a gracious Providence will crown our righteous and glorious efforts with I have the honor to be, most respectfully and cordially, your fellow-citizen,

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted, a Substitute to go in a No. 1 artillery company.
None need apply unless he is over 45 years old, sound and healthy, and with a character well endorsed.
For such an one a liberal price will be paid.
A Virginian preferred.
Apply at the office corner of Wall and Franklin sts.

div3.head: Two Substitutes Wanted.
div3.p:
--Will have the choice of enlisting in any company or branch of the service that they may desire.
Call at Brown & Turner's, on the Basin Sank, between the hours of 2 and 4.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be given for a sound and reliable man over 45 years of age, to go as a Substitute in a No. 1 infantry company.
Apply at the Saw Mill, Mayo's Bridge.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For one that will suit a fair price will be paid.
Apply immediately to.
div3.closer:
A D Williams.
Opposite P O Department. fe 12--3t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in an infantry company.
For one over 45 years of age, I will give $2,000. Apply at
div3.closer: A. Eddins's, on Mayo street, for three days. fe 12--3t*

div3.head: Married.
div3.p:
On Friday, 6th instant, by Rev. W A Smith, D D, President of Randolph Macon College, Lieut J Thompson Brown, of Richmond, and Miss.
Bettie H Harrison, of Mecklenburg county, Va.

div4.p: On Tuesday evening, at 8 o'clock, of pneumonia, Samuel King, son of James H and Virginia Love, aged 8 months and 2 days.
The funeral will take place from Trinity Church, (Rev. Dr. Edwards,) this morning, at 11 o'clock.--Friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.
At the residence of Mr. S P Mitchell, on Wednesday morning, the 11th inst, Mrs. Margaret M Baker, relief of the late Hilary Baker, Esq, in the 70th year of her age.
The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend her funeral, at Grace Church, on Friday morning at 11 o'clock.
on Saturday, Feb. 7, 1863, at half-past 10 o'clock, after a short illness, Mary Fanny, the only daughter of Anderson and Mary Carnell, aged 17 years 4 months and 21 days.

lg.l: sleep in peace within the grave,
cares no longer pain thy breast,
in thy deep and quiet rest.
Storms no longer round then roll,
Sins no longer vex thy soul;
Parting words are heard no more,
With the blood washed saints on high,

div4.p: On 7th February, 1863, Harry Herbert, son of Louisa V and the late James H Walthall, aged 4 years 10 months and 4 days.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Died, in Fredericksburg, on the 13th January, of pneumonia, Thomas C. Carrington, of Company C, 32d Regiment of Va, Infantry.

It may be well said of young Carrington that he was truly a soldier and a gentleman.
Possessing in an eminent degree all the lofty attributes of that heroic patriotism that has shone so gloriously throughout the South from the beginning of the war; blessed with a person of manly mould; punctilious in his sense of duty; refined in feeling, liberal in his views, and full of generous friendship, he has left a void in the ranks of the 32d, though death is no stranger there.
He had the confidence and esteem of his officers, not less than the affection of his comrades in the camp.
In the full vigor of early manhood he has passed away.
We lament him among the dead, but not the lost.
Died, at his residence, on Franklin st, on the night of the 6th inst., Samuel S. Scruggs, aged 42 years.

Mr. Scruggs was formerly a member of the Powhatan Artillery, and was honorably discharged because of physical disability.
At the time of his death he was in Government employ, and died from disease contracted while in service.
He was quiet and unassuming in his manners, and his intercourse with men was marked by candor and honesty.
He was an earnest, pious Christian, and prayed fervently just before dying.
In private, none could be more tenderly affectionate, nor more solicitous for the welfare of her now left a lonely widow.
In her bereavement we would tender our warmest sympathies, humbly trusting that He who "tempereth the winds to the shorn lamb" will likewise heal the wound which He has seen fit to inflict. *

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Owners.--Owners of the following Slaves are requested to call at Small-pox Hospital, No. 1, and take charge of them, as they are now convalescent:
Leona, Mr. Gill, (on 6th street) came in Nov. 23d, 1862.
Balaam, Dr. Murphy, (Florida Hospital) came in Nov. 30th, 1862
Catherine, Wyatt Mills, came in Dec. 13th, 1862
Kkn, Dr. Ball, Homes's agent, came in Jan. 6th, 1863.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A young lady, a graduate of a Virginia Institute, and competent to teach English, including Algebre, Ceametry, and French, deattes a Situation in a seminary or family.--Address "Alpha," Old Church, Hanover county.
Va.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Marble Outters.--We wish to employ a good Letterer in Marble.
A steady hand can get a good job. Apply in person as soon as possible to

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A small House, suitable for two ladies and four children, in the immediate vicinity of Camp Lee.
A small house, with two or three rooms, would answer.
Address, stating terms, "A S M," Richmond P O.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Boom with beard, or from alone, for two gentlemen connected with one of the Departments.
Address "Box B," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A French lady, from Paris, desires a situation in a family as Teacher of the French language.
Haying had long experience she hopes to give satisfaction.
Apply at the American Hotel.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A situation as Bookkeeper.--A young man who has several hours of leisure during the day, is desirous of occupying his time in writing up books and accounts.
He has had several years' experience as an accountant, writes a good hand, and can offer good reference.
Any one wishing to employ him will please address. "J. H.," Dispatch Office.

div3.head: Eight hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --A reward of $100 each is offered for the following named privates of company F, 19th Va. regiment:

James Gafiney, a short, stout man, sandy hair and beard, blue eyes, about 35 years old; enlisted as a substitute near Richmond, about August 8, 1862; called himself a Kentuckian, and had a discharge from the 1st Kentucky regiment.
John Hogan, a short, stout Irishman; black hair and eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high looks about 30 years old; will be found near Richmond, enlisted as a substitute in December, 1862.
Martin Kelley, about 5 feet high, very dark complexion, dark hair, thin dark beard, supposed to have enlisted in the 4th Virginia cavalry.
Richard Matthews, an Irishman, hair and beard, about 5 feet 9 inches high.
div3.closer:
Eennrtt Taylor, Capt Co. F,
19th Varegt. fe 12--3t*

div3.head: One hundred Dollar reward.
div3.p:
--Left my company, (A 510 Va. reg't,) on or about the 7th day of January, 1863 Thomas Molean.
He is about 5 feet 8 inches high, with dark hair.
The middle finger of his right hand has been out off just below the second joint.
On the back of the other hand is a large star in India ink. He also has a small ring in his right ear. The above reward well be paid for his delivery to me, at the camp of the 53d Va. reg't, Armistead's brigade, Pickett's division, near Guinea Station.

div3.head: Thirty Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at Marine Camp, Drewry's Bluff, of Wm. Myers, a deserter from the C S Marine Corns.
He is 23 years of age, 5 feet 8¼ inches high, blue eyes, light hair, fair complexion.
He had been wounded in the left hand supposed to escaping from Camp Lee, where he had engaged himself and substitute.
div3.closer:
A S Taylor,
Major and Q M C S M C,
Office 115 Broad st. fe 12--6t

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--to the citizens of Henrico.--The undersigned having been detained for thirty days on recruiting service for the county of Henrico, hereby announces to its citizens the partial suspension of the conscript act, so as to allow all conscripts in this county to volunteer in companies of their own selection in this division, and thereby receive the usual bounty of 850 awarded to volunteers.
It is earnestly hoped thus these inducements will add a large number of men to the ranks of the army.
I call upon the people of this county to assist me in the good work.
Let every man apply his shoulder to the whell, and by a determined effort to forward the good work, show to the people of the country that the county of Henrico has not forgotten her duty.
I also call upon the citizens of this county to assist me in returning to duty deserters from the army, who are now at home skulking from their duty, while their fellow soldiers are suffering from the cold and expesure of the winter.
To all such I would say, that I will make every endeavor to arrest them, and return them to their respective companies.
To those wishing to volunteer I would say, that I can be found over the store of Solden & Miller, No. 15 Cary street, between the hours of 9 and 3 o'clock, every day.

div3.head: Important to conscripts, Stragglers, and Desesters.
div3.p:
--In accordance with order No. 39, issued by Major General Geo. W. Smith, we hereupon assume the duties of Recruiting Snipers for the county of Henrico, city of Richmond, and vicinity.
all concerned, notice is hereby given that the operation of the Conscript law is partialty suspended in this department.
Any person wishing to volunteer will be allowed to select his own company, provided it be in this Department, and will be entitled to the bounty and all other benefits which are provided for by law to volunteers.
In like manner all conscripts who come forward voluntarily and make application to this office will be enrolled into any company they may select in this command.
It is hoped and believed that the liberal inducements herein tendered to conscripts will meet with a prompt response, and thus aid in securing ample means for the common defence.

By like command we are instructed to arrest all strugglars and deserters from the army.
To those who report voluntarily we are authorized to declare a free and full pardon, with the exception of forfeiture of pay for the time absent.
Those who fall to report will be arrested and confined until they can be forwarded to their companies under guard.
The co-operation of the people in discountenancing straggling and inducing the inggard to return to duty is hereby earnestly invoked.
We can be found at any time between the houre of 10 A. M. and 3 P. M, in the Military Hall, above the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main sts.

div3.head: Notice to
div3.p: At possession construct age, thorfaced to appear before his for will report immediately.
div3.closer:
John A Coke, Capt and Ruroll'g Officer
3d Congressional District, fe 11--ts

div3.head: Commissioner's sale.
div3.p: --On Wednesday, the 14th inst., I will sell, as Commissioner, at the auction house of Lee & James, in this city, a likely Woman--No. 1 field hand.
